title: Boris Johnson wins vote for General Election on December 12
text:
Boris Johnson won a vote to have an election on December 12 (Picture: EPA)

MPs have voted to have an early General Election on December 12.

They voted in favour of the bill by a huge majority of 418.

It came after Labour lost an amendment to go to the polls three days earlier, on December 9.

The Prime Minister wanted a pre-Christmas election on December 12 – declaring the need for a ‘new and revitalised’ Parliament which is able to deliver Brexit.

The government said a December 9 election would require parliament to be dissolved at the end of Thursday, making it ‘very difficult’ to get key legislation through the house.

However, opposition parties expressed concern students may have broken up for Christmas by December 12 and it could be harder to get them to vote if they are travelling between two locations.

MPs voted for the December 12 election by a majority of 418 (Picture: AFP)

The win for Boris Johnson means voters will go to the polls in six weeks time.

A new Prime Minister will be declared on Friday 13th December.

Speaking after the result, Boris Johnson told reporters it’ll be a ‘tough election’ and said it was time for the country to ‘come together to get Brexit done’.

He called for the election after MPs forced him to ask the EU for a three month delay to the October 31 Brexit deadline.

In a statement, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said it was a ‘once-in-a-generation chance’ to transform the country and ‘take on the vested interests holding people back.’

He said: ‘The choice at this election could not be clearer. A Labour government will be on your side, while Boris Johnson’s Conservatives – who think they’re born to rule – will only look after the privileged few.

‘We will now launch the most ambitious and radical campaign for real change that our country has ever seen.

‘This is our chance to build a country for the many not the few and fit for the next generation.’

Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson welcomed the result, vowing to Stop Brexit and ‘build a brighter future’ for the country.

Speaking on Sky News she said: ‘This general election will decide the future of our country for generations. It is our best chance to elect a government to stop Brexit.
